thread.section_title: London says ‘business as usual’ in defiance against terror attack – Metro
thread.title: London says ‘business as usual’ in defiance against terror attack
thread.title_full: London says ‘business as usual’ in defiance against terror attack

author: georgiadiebelius1
title: London says ‘business as usual’ in defiance against terror attack
text:
Armed Police stand guard on Embankment outside the Houses of Parliament (Picture: Neil Mockford/Getty Images) London has returned to normal this morning – less than 24 hours after yesterday’s terror attack.
Four people – including the suspect – died after a man with two knives injured around 40 people.
How to perform CPR in three steps and what does CPR stand for? He mowed down pedestrians with a car on Westminster Bridge before crashing at the railings in front of Parliament and stabbing PC Keith Palmer to death.
The suspect was shot dead by armed officers at the scene.
This morning, Metropolitan Police declared ‘business as normal’ in the capital.
Police remain ate the scene (Picture: Matthew Chattle/REX/Shutterstock) Commuters are returning to work as normal, with Underground tubes packed full.
Donald Trump Jr used London terror attack to peddle anti-Muslim hate Westminster Tube station, however, remains closed.
Cordons have now been lifted on Lambeth Palace Road and York Road so drivers can return.
For those travelling on the tube, people can use Westminster as an interchange to change onto the Jubilee, Circle and District line but cannot enter or leave the station.
Both the House of Commons and Lords will sit at their usual times, parliamentary authorities have announced.
The immediate return to normal sitting hours is to be seen as a sign of determination that the UK’s democratic processes will not be disrupted by what is believed to be a terrorist attack.
The House of Commons will return as normal (Picture: PA) A spokesman for the police said they were ‘absolutely certain’ that Parliament could work as usual’.
Four Lancashire students among 40 injured in London terror attack The Commons will sit at 9.30am for questions to International Trade Secretary Liam Fox and a statement from Leader of the House David Lidington.
This will be followed by debates on compensation for Equitable Life policy-holders, social mobility and an incinerator in the Hertfordshire village of Hoddesdon.
What happened outside Parliament Members of the emergency services work to help vicitms on Westminster Bridge, alongside the Houses of Parliament in central London on March 22, 2017, during an emergency incident (Picture: Getty) A massive police investigationis under way after a terror attack in central London.
Here’s everything we know so far about the Westminster attack:
Four people have died – a police officer, the attacker, a woman in her mid 40s, named as and a man in his mid 50s.
The officer was Pc Keith Palmer, a 48-year-old husband and father with 15 years of police service.
Seven people have been arrested and six addresses raided across London, Birmingham and elsewhere.
The woman was killed on Westminster Bridge as a number of pedestrians were mowed down by a grey Hyundai i40.
It is believed the man was also killed in the incident on the bridge.
Seven people are in a critical condition, and 29 have been treated in hospital.
One woman ended up in the Thames and was treated for serious injuries after being pulled from the water.
The attacker, armed with two large knives, jumped out of the car after smashing it into the railings encircling the Palace of Westminster, fatally stabbing Pc Palmer as he entered the grounds.
He was shot dead moments later by another officer.
Defence Secretary Michael Fallon has said the working assumption is that the attack is linked to Islamic terrorism.
A group of French schoolchildren were among those targeted on the bridge, with three injured.
Prime Minister Theresa May later chaired a meeting of the Government’s emergency Cobra committee, branding the attack ‘sick and depraved’.
 
Emergency services rushed to the scene (Picture: Universal News And Sport) The Lords will convene at 11am for oral questions on nursery care, support for young carers, premium bonds and famine in Africa before debate on homelessness, science and Brexit.
National minute's sentence at 9.33am and vigil at 6pm in Trafalgar Square It is not yet known whether any special steps will be taken in the chamber to mark yesterday’s horrific incidents – or to honour the innocent people who died.
In a statement, a Parliamentary spokesman said only: ‘We can confirm that both the House of Commons and the House of Lords will sit tomorrow at their normal times.’
